ygData.subject: Re: Introduction---recurrency question
ygData.msgSnippet: John (caloyannis) is right when he says the trick is to find it! I think it s important to keep in mind in discussions such as this one that theoretical

John (caloyannis) is right when he says the "trick is to find it!"

I think it's important to keep in mind in discussions such as this 
one that theoretical facts are usually of little practical 
consequence.  That recurrent networks can represent any Turing 
machine is about as practically useful as knowing that you can 
theoretically build a fully-functioning computer out of water pipes 
and water.  The real question with respect to recurrent NN's is 
what's reasonably easy to find and represent, not what's 
theoretically possible.  Also note that what's easy to find is not 
always so much a property of the neural network alone as a property 
of the search process used to generate it combined with the type of 
neural network.  

In any case, my point is that it certainly merits long and deep 
discussion what can or cannot be done with a recurrent network, 
regardless of what is possible in theory, even if all things are 
possible in theory.  We are generally interested in practice, which 
is much more complicated, which is also why it's fun: There is a lot 
of room for creativity and in fact standard recurrent structures may 
indeed be more difficult to discover than other memory-based 
realizations such as Hebbian networks.  For this reason, we should 
keep an open mind.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "johncaloyannis" <johncaloyannis@y...> 
wrote:
> Hello everybody
> 
> I started dabbling in AI abouit twenty years ago on and off. For a
> while  I thought that genetic programming could be an avenue to 
follow
> (Koza). However lately I came across the NEAT concept which I found
> fascinating since it combines the best of both worlds (neural 
networks
> + evolution).
> I have followed the discussions you guys have with interest. I 
think
> that since the recurrent neural networks are intractable
> mathematically, apart from some very special cases (hopfield), one 
can
> only speculate and experiment to learn things.
> Regarding the discussion about the recurrency question and what a 
RNN
> can or can not do there is a very interesting paper which proves 
that
> there is a turing machine for every RNN and vice-versa. Since 
anything
> that is computable can be achieved with a turing machine so can it
> through an RNN. The trick is to find it :)
> http://www.uwasa.fi/stes/step96/step96/hyotyniemi1
